bibl.title: Fletcher Decker v. State of Washington. Decision

keywords.term: Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF FLETCHER DECKER FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS AND WRIT OF CHRTI- ORARI.
D E C I S I O N.
Filed Sept. 15. 1921.
Beeler & Sullivan, Attorneys for Petitioner.
Charlotte Kolmitz, Asst. U.S. Atty and Robt. C. Saunders. U.S. Atty, Attorneys for United States.
Tucker & Hyland, Attorneys for Dominion of Canada.
NETERER, District Judge, - - - - -

The petitioner seeks release because of illegal detention predicated upon the fact that the warrant of arrest is illegal for the reason that, first: "That the complaint made and filed with said commissioner fails to show that said commissioner had jurisdiction in matters relating to extradi- tion and second, that said warrant of arrest fails to recite, allege or show upon its face that the said commissioner who issued the same as aforesaid had any right or power or author- ity in law to issue the same."

The petitioner bases his application upon In Re Ferez, 8 Fed. Cas. 4544, In Re Kelley, 25 Fed. 268; In Re McDonnell, 16 Fed. Cas. 8771; U.S. vs. Stowwell, 27 Fed. Cas. 16409; Exparte Lane, 6 Fed. 34; Byrne's Fed. Crim. Proc. 26; 19 Cyc. 68; Bishop's New Crim. Proc. Sec. 187; 1 Cooley on Torta, p. 302; Anderson on Jud. Writs & Proc. p. 36, 112; Com. vs. Fay, 112 Mass. 235.

In obedience to the writ the United States Marshal produced the petitioner and stated that he held the said petitioner pursuant to judgment and commitment of United States Commissioner, an Extradition Commissioner, and there- with produced the record of the Commissioner in support of such judgment and commitment. It appears that complaint was
filed before the U.S. Commissioner and warrant issued. The warrant was served upon the petitioner, who thereupon appeared before the United States Commissioner and voluntarily entered into a recognizance in writing for his appearance before the Commissioner at a fixed date and was released. At the appoint- ed time he appeared and through his counsel objected to the jurisdiction of the commissioner; upon the ground that the warrant its face does not disclose that the commissioner had been empowered to hear extradition proceedings and the complaint was insufficient. An amended complaint was thereupon filed, and the petitioner demurred to the sufficiency of the complaint for the reason that the complaint filed before the magistrate in Canada was insufficient to support extradition. The mat- ter proceeded to trial; testimony was introduced, and the Commissioner found the petitioner to be the identical party charged who committed an offense contrary to the Criminal Code of Canada, covered by the Extradition Convention between the United States of America and the Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and proclaimed by the President of the United States of America on the 25th day of March, 1890, supplemental to the Tenth Article of the treaty concluded between the same High Contracting Parties on the 9th day of Agust, 1843, and directed the Marshal to commit the petitioner until such sur- ender shall be made to the Province of Saskatchewan of the petitioner. The judgment recites that the said Commissioner was authorized, commissioned and appointed United States Commissioner in and for the Western District of Washington to hear and determine all matters of extradition, and to act in the matter of the prosecution of fugitives from justice
from foreign countries. In the order of commitment the recital was omitted.

The cases cited by the petitioner were deter- mined upon issues deemed vital othen than the fact that the warrant of arrest failed to show that the Commissioner had authority in law to issue the same under the Extradition Act. Judge Brown in Exparte Lane, supra, at 37, said:

"I should be loath, however, to hold that the proceedings were void upon this account****since I am by no means certain that the court upon an application for discharge upon a writ of habeas corpus woul dbe bound to take judicial notice of the fact that the Com- missioner had been appointed for this purpose."
It is not necessary to a decision in this case to pass upon the question as to whether the court is bound to judically know that the Commissioner was appointed for this purpose.

The Supreme Court in In Re Cortez, Petitioner, 136 U.S. 330, held that if the Commissioner has jurisdiction of the subject matter and if the person, and the offense charged is within the terms of the treaty of extradition, and competent legal evidence is produced upon which to predicate his conclusion, the conclusion of the Commissioner may not be reviewed

This Court does judicially know that the Com- missioner was appointed for this purpose, but his knowledge is not vital to this issue. Extradition proceedings are not viewed with that technical nicety as obtains in the final trial of a criminal issue. When the petitioner entered into recognizance without objection and was released from the operation of the warrant, he waived any irregularity or infor- mality in the warrant, and after entry into recognizance he responded by force of the recognizance and not by force of the warrant. Lancey vs. State, 16 N. E. 504 (Ind.); State vs. Shedder, 44 Pac. 34 (Kan.); State vs. Goff, 61 Pac. 680 (Kan.)
Washburn vs. People, 10 Mich. 372; People vs. Jones, 24 Mich. 214; People vs. Turner, 74 N. W. 519. The fact that the Commissioner had no right to release the petitioner on bail is immaterial since the petitioner was in fact released, nor is it material that the recognizance given was without force, since the petitioner voluntarily presented himself, and when the amended complaint was filed before the Commissioner he voluntarily pleaded thereto, submitting himself to the jur- isdiction, and thereby waivd any irregularity or informality in the complaint, cases supra; and the fact that the Commis- sioner signed the commitment as United States Commissioner, failing to add as Extradition Commissioner, or to certify such fact in the commitment, under the record in this cas can only be held a clerical omission and not vital. State vs. William- son, 81 N.C. 540.
The writ is discharged.
Neterer J U D G E.
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT Western District of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION SEP 15 1921 F.M. Harshberger, Clerk By S.E. Leitch Deputy
